Fax: +86 28 85418451. Graphical abstract In this work, CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3 (CZA) composites promoted by selective doping with Ba were prepared by simple coprecipitation method. The structural characterization results reveal that with small doping amount (≤6wt%), Ba can preferentially combine with Al2O3 and acts as a stabilizer, which could facilitate the formation of more homogeneous CZ solid solutions. When the content of BaO increases to 8wt%, besides the portion combined with Al2O3, the remnant Ba would enter into the lattice of CeO2–ZrO2 to form a ternary CeO2–ZrO2–BaO solid solution, thus further improved oxygen mobility is obtained. However, excessive doping amount (10wt%) brings about self-aggregation of BaO, which seriously deteriorates the structure of the CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3-BaO composite. The XPS results demonstrate that with optimal doping content of BaO (8wt%), the supported catalyst Pd/CZAB8 possesses highest surface Pd and Ce3+ concentrations, which consequently leads to improved reducibility and catalytic performance. Furthermore, the synergistic effect between CeO2–ZrO2–BaO and BaO–Al2O3 helps improve the thermal stability of Pd/CZAB8. Thus, superior textural, structural, morphological and reduction properties along with enhanced three-way catalytic performance are obtained for aged Pd/CZAB8a. Keywords CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3 composites Selective doping CeO2–ZrO2–BaO solid solution Self-aggregation Three-way catalytic performance 1 Introduction CeO2-based materials have attracted considerable research interest for more than half a century owing to its far-ranging applications in fuel cell, solid-state electrolyte, gas sensors, and especially as promoters in three-way catalysts (TWCs) [1–4]. The TWC technology is crucial to the de-pollution process in exhaust purification systems of ubiquitous automobiles on account of its high efficiency to simultaneously convert the harmful hydrocarbons (HCs), CO and NOx to environmentally friendly H2O, CO2, and N2 [5–7]. Generally speaking, the highest simultaneous conversions of the three contaminations over TWCs are attained at air/fuel ratios (A/F) close to the stoichiometric value (14.6), while fluctuations to rich (net reducing) or lean (net oxidizing) conditions would result in severe decreased conversion efficiency [5,6]. Thus, the OSC of CeO2 originated from the reversible transformation of Ce4+ and Ce3+, which can act as an oxygen buffer to compensate the fluctuations in the exhaust stream, is of great technological importance in TWCs [1,8–10]. Since the past decades it has been demonstrated that incorporation of Zr into the CeO2-based system could result in the formation of CexZr1-xO2 solid solutions, which exhibit modified textural, structural, redox properties along with enhanced thermal stability at elevated temperatures [11,12]. Hence, CexZr1-xO2 composites have gradually replaced pure CeO2 to use as the OSC promoters in TWCs [5,8]. In the typical design of modern TWC, alumina (Al2O3) is often used as a carrier due to its large specific surface area as well as considerably high thermal stability under extremely high temperature conditions of the exhausts [8]. Till date Al2O3 supported CexZr1-xO2 materials have been extensively used and demonstrated to be the most advanced support materials in TWCs [13–17]. Previous researchers have testified that the strong interaction between CexZr1-xO2 and Al2O3 components can bring about improved textural and redox properties as well as enhanced thermal resistance compared with single CexZr1-xO2 or Al2O3 [14–16,18,19]. However, it is found from our preliminary work that the introduction of Al2O3 into the Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 system would disrupt the homogeneous structure of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, some Zr-rich species closely contact with Al2O3, leading to the observed CZ nanocrystallites richer in Ce, which is detrimental to the oxygen mobility and consequently gives rise to undesirable redox property of the composite [20]. Ba is declared to be an excellent promoter for Al2O3, which can effectively retard the loss of specific surface area and suppress the phase transformation of Al2O3 upon high temperature treatment [8,21]. Therefore, in this work, Ba is introduced into the Ce0.5Zr0.5O2–Al2O3 system. By preferentially doping Al2O3 with BaO, Al2O3 can be well stabilized without destroying the homogeneous structure of CZ, and appropriate amount of Ba may exert a positive influence on both CZ and Al2O3 components. On the other hand, nowadays the cost-effective Pd-only three-way catalysts have low purification performance of NOx compared with Rh-containing catalysts, which limits their extensive application [22–25]. And the introduction of basic additives, for instance, Ba, is thought to be an effective method by donating an electron to Pd to bring it closer to the electron configuration of Rh, and thus reduced NO dissociation enthalpy and improved purification performance of NO can be obtained [22]. In addition, BaO-based catalysts have been proven to be highly efficient as NOx storage/reduction catalysts [26,27], and other researchers [23,28] have found that Ba-modified CexZr1-xO2-supported Pd-only catalysts have high conversion efficiency and wide operation window of NOx. Thus the introduction of Ba into the CZA system may give rise to a good candidate to support the Pd-only three-way catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3–BaO composites Five CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3–BaO composites with Ce/Zr=1/1 (mol%), Ce0.5Zr0.5O2/Al2O3 =1/1 (wt%) and various contents of BaO (0, 4, 6, 8, 10wt%) were prepared by simultaneous coprecipitation method. First, required amounts of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, ZrO(NO3)2, Al(NO3)3·9H2O and Ba(NO3)2 were dissolved in water to obtain a mixed salt solution, and a buffer solution composed of ammonia and ammonium carbonate was applied as the precipitant. The mixed salt solution was blended with the base solution under vigorous stirring, afterwards the obtained mixture was further aged at 90°C for 6h to promote the complete precipitation. Then the precipitate was filtrated and washed with distilled water until no pH changes could be detected. After that the obtained cake was submitted to drying at 100°C for 24h and calcining at 600°C for 3h to finally get the powder samples, which were henceforth labeled as CZABx (x = 0, 4, 6, 8, 10 which represented the mass ratios of BaO in the composites). To study the thermal evolution of the CZABx materials, the as-prepared CZABx samples were further treated at 1000°C for 5h, and the aged samples were hereafter designated as CZABxa. 2.2 Preparation of the monolith catalysts The above-mentioned CZABx materials were employed as the carriers to support the active component Pd. A conventional wet-impregnation method was used and the academic loading amount of Pd was 0.5wt% for all catalysts. First, Pd(NO3)2 aqueous solutions were impregnated on CZABx powders, and then the impregnated samples were dried at 120°C for 2h and subsequently calcined at 550°C for 3h. Afterwards the samples were introduced into distilled water and ball milled to get slurries with solid content of 40wt%, which were then coated onto the cylindrical cordierite monoliths (Corning, USA, 400cells/in.2, 2.5cm3), and the excess slurry was blown away by compressed air. After that the monolith catalysts were dried at 120°C for 2h and calcined at 550°C for 3h to finally obtain the fresh catalysts, which were henceforward marked as Pd/CZABx. The fresh catalysts were also submitted to treating at 1000°C for 5h and labeled as Pd/CZABxa for the purpose of investigating the thermal stability. 2.3 Evaluation of the three-way catalytic performance The three-way catalytic activity was tested using a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. The monolith catalysts were placed in a stainless steel tube. The simulated exhaust gases were composed of C3H8 (0.012%), C3H6 (0.024%), CO (0.56%), H2 (0.19%), NO (0.10%), H2O (10%), CO2 (12%), O2 (adjustable) and N2 was used as the balance. The feed stream was regulated by special mass flow controllers before entering the blender and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was controlled at 40,000h−1. Before the testing procedure, the catalysts were pretreated under flowing gas mixture at 550°C for at least 1h. The λ value of the simulated gases, which stands for the ratio between available oxygen and oxygen required for complete conversions to CO2, H2O and N2, can be described as λ ={[NO]+2[O2]}/{10[C3H8]+9[C3H6]+[H2]+[CO]}, and λ =1 was utilized at all testing points. The compositions of the inlet and outlet gas mixtures were analyzed by an FT-IR (Antaris IGS-6700, Nicolet, Thermo Fisher Scientific), accordingly the conversions of HC, CO, NO and the N2 selectivity were calculated. 2.4 Characterization techniques The textural characterization was performed using a Quantachrome automated surface area & pore size analyzer (Autosorb SI). The samples were firstly degassed at 300°C for 3h and then measured using N2 adsorption–desorption at liquid N2 temperature (−196°C). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected with a Rigaku DX-2500 diffractometer. The experiment was carried out at 100mA, 40kV and Cu Kα (λ =0.15406nm) was applied as the radiation source. The spectra with a range of scan at 10°≤2θ≤80° and a step size of 0.03° were recorded. The Raman spectra were obtained using a LabRAM HR Laser Raman spectrometer (HORIBA JOBIN YVON, France) equipped with a YAG laser. The excitation wavelength was chosen to be 532nm, and the measurement was operated at a laser power of 73.5mW. The spectra acquisition contained 3 accumulations in 30s for each sample with a resolution of 0.65cm−1, and the collected frequency range was 100–1000cm−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were collected using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN TEM (FEI Company, USA) equipped with STEM, HAADF and EDX systems. Prior to the experiment, the powder specimens were suspended in ethanol and dispersed by ultrasonic, and then a droplet of the suspension was deposited on a perforated carbon film supported by a copper grid. The measurement was performed at an accelerating voltage of 200kV. Scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800, Japan) was used to observe the morphological features of the samples, and the accelerating voltage was 5.0kV. The surface elemental information was recorded by an XSAM-800 electron spectrometer (Kratos, British) equipped with Mg Kα (1253.6eV) as the radiation. The measurement was operated at 13kV, 20mA. The XPS data correlated with Ce 3d, Zr 3d, Al 2p, Ba 3d and Pd 3d core levels were acquired for all samples, and C 1s peak at 284.6eV was regarded as the internal standard reference to correct the surface charging effect. The reduction characteristics were determined by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using a self-assembled reaction system equipped with a gas chromatograph. 100mg sample was used for each test, before the reduction process, the sample was pretreated under flowing N2 (25mlmin−1) at 450°C for 1h. After the system was cooled down to room temperature, the sample was heated at a constant heating rate of 8°Cmin−1 under a flowing gas mixture of H2 (5vol%) in N2 (20mlmin−1), and the signal was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural results The textural properties of the fresh and aged catalysts, including specific surface areas, pore volumes and mean pore radii, are determined by N2 adsorption–desorption method and the results are summarized in Table 1 . For the fresh samples, it is found that the introduction of Ba exerts little influence on the textural property of CZA system except for Pd/CZAB10, the surface area and pore volume of which become obviously smaller. In addition, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms in Fig. 1 are similar with each other. As can be seen therein, the isotherms of all fresh samples can be identified as type IV, characteristic of mesoporous structure according to the IUPAC definition [29]. And H2-type hysteresis loops are observed, which is indicative of the presence of ink-bottle-type pores. After aging treatment, the samples undergo sintering to different extents, as displayed in Table 1, all samples exhibit declined surface areas and pore volumes, and the increased pore radii are induced by the elimination of smaller pores and formation of larger ones during the sintering process [30]. The sintering behavior can be testified by the changes in the isotherms as well. From Fig. 1b, it is seen that the shapes of the isotherms for the aged samples are significantly different from those for the fresh samples, all curves in Fig. 1b feature H1-type hysteresis loops associated with cylindrical pores, and the closing points of the hysteresis loops shift to higher relative pressure (P/P 0), coinciding with the larger pore radii of the aged samples. What should be pointed out is that, the textural properties of the Ba-containing samples appear to be deteriorated to lesser extents compared with that of Pd/CZAB0, indicating that the introduction of Ba can improve the thermal stability of the CZA system. In addition, it is also found from Table 1 that Pd/CZAB8a possesses largest surface area and pore volume among all aged samples, which is beneficial to maintain high catalytic performance. 3.2 XRD characterization Fig. 2 presents the XRD patterns of all samples, the lattice constants and crystallite sizes, calculated based on the Bragg’s Law and Sherrer Equation, respectively, are compiled in Table 2 . As seen in Fig. 2a, the main diffraction peaks of the fresh samples are characteristic of cubic fluorite CeO2, implying the formation of CeO2-based solid solutions [11]. No peaks identified as γ-Al2O3 can be observed for the fresh samples except for Pd/CZAB10. Considering that Al2O3 cannot enter into the framework of CZ to form ternary CZA solid solution [16], it can be deduced that Al2O3 is in a well dispersed state and the grain size is too small to be detected by XRD technique. For Pd/CZAB0, the lattice parameter is obviously larger than the theoretical value of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (0.5268nm), which means that owing to the existence of Al2O3, the homogeneity of CZ solid solution is destroyed, some Zr-rich species closely contact with Al2O3, resulting in the Ce-rich characteristic of the observed CZ phase [20]. For the Ba-containing samples, it is noticed that the main diffraction peaks shift to higher angles with low Ba contents and for samples with Ba contents higher than 6wt%, the diffraction peaks conversely shift towards lower angles. Also, the lattice parameters listed in Table 2 show a decreasing tendency from Pd/CZAB0 to Pd/CZAB6 and subsequently increase when Ba content further increases. Considering that Ba is an excellent promoter and stabilizer for Al2O3 [8,21], introduction of small amount of Ba may selectively combine with Al2O3, which could facilitate the incorporation of Zr into the lattice of CeO2 to form homogeneous CZ solid solutions. Thus, it is understandable that Pd/CZAB4 and Pd/CZAB6 own smaller lattice parameters than the sample without Ba, which agrees well with the previous research that for CexZr1-xO2-BaO·Al2O3 nanocomposite, CexZr1-xO2 component could enhance the capability of self-assembling by forcing Ba to interact with Al2O3 [31]. And it is worthwhile to point out that the lattice parameter of Pd/CZAB6 approximates to that of bare Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, implying that for this sample, the amount of Ba is enough to stabilize Al2O3, thus homogeneous CZ solid solution is formed which appears insusceptible to Al2O3. In the case of Pd/CZAB8, the lattice parameter becomes larger than that of Pd/CZAB6, which may be interpreted as the incorporation of the remaining Ba (with larger ionic radius, 1.35Å) into the lattice of CZ. A perusal of Fig. 1a reveals that some peak-splitting appears in the diffraction pattern of Pd/CZAB10, which seems to be the evidence of the presence of BaO phase. However, the characteristic peaks of BaO phase locate at diffraction angles (28.87, 33.41 and 48.02 ° for (111), (200) and (220) planes) close to those of cubic CZ phase, making it difficult to distinguish accurately. This phenomenon hints us that introduction of excessive amount of Ba may bring about self-aggregation of BaO, which exerts negative influence on the structure of Pd/CZAB10, and further accounts for the larger lattice parameter of Pd/CZAB10 and the appearance of diffraction peaks characteristic of γ-Al2O3 phase. In addition, it can be inferred from Table 2 that smaller crystallite sizes can be obtained by introduction of appropriate amount of Ba, but excessive amount of Ba (10wt%) results in larger crystallite size of CZ. Thermal treating at 1000°C brings about obvious peak sharpening, indicating significant grain growth for all samples. As can be seen in Fig. 2b, visible γ-Al2O3 phase is detected for all aged samples, but no traces of θ-Al2O3 or δ-Al2O3 are found, demonstrating that the phase transformation of Al2O3 is effectively suppressed. For CZ-based phase, it is seen that the lattice parameter of Pd/CZAB0a is smaller than its corresponding fresh counterpart, which may be ascribed to the higher concentration of Zr in the lattice of CeO2 [20,32]. For Pd/CZAB4a, the lattice variation resembles that of Pd/CZAB0a. However, Pd/CZAB6a and Pd/CZAB8a show only slight lattice variations, suggesting higher structural stability of these two samples, which may be ascribed to the synergistic stabilizing effect between CZ/CZBa and BaO-Al2O3. In the case of Pd/CZAB10a, self-aggregation of BaO can also be evidenced by the presence of characteristic peaks of BaO, and in the meantime, the homogeneity of CZ solid solution is deteriorated, as seen in Table 2, Pd/CZAB10a possesses relatively larger lattice parameter. On the other hand, from Table 2 it is found that the introduction of Ba helps inhibit the grain growth of CZ, Pd/CZAB6a and Pd/CZAB8a maintain relatively smaller crystallite sizes, which is beneficial to the preservation of high surface area and available surface species. 3.3 Raman characterization To obtain some additional details of the structural information, Raman characterization is performed and the profiles are depicted in Fig. 3 . As reported in the literatures [33,34], the Raman band at around 465cm−1 is associated with the F2g mode of cubic fluorite CeO2. When Zr4+ with smaller ionic radius enters into the framework of CeO2, the Raman band would shift to higher wave number owing to the shorter MO bond length. And the principal peak of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 is located at about 472cm−1 [35]. It can be seen from Fig. 3a that the main peaks of the fresh samples are typical of cubic fluorite CeO2. And the lower Raman frequencies of Pd/CZAB0 and Pd/CZAB4 coincide with the Ce-rich characteristic of the cubic phase, as demonstrated by the XRD results. For Pd/CZAB6, the Raman band locates at the same position as that of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, suggesting the formation of homogeneous CZ solid solution. When the content of Ba further increases to 8 wt%, the incorporation of the remaining Ba into the lattice of CZ gives rise to lower Raman frequency of Pd/CZAB8. In the case of Pd/CZAB10, an additional band at 989cm−1 appears, which is probably originated from the Raman vibration of BaO [36,37], this further confirms the existence of BaO phase in Pd/CZAB10. After aging treatment, some phase segregation can be observed from Fig. 3b. According to the literatures [33,34], the Raman spectrum of tetragonal ZrO2 features six peaks (A1g +2B1g +3Eg) centered at around 147, 268, 313, 460, 600 and 645cm−1. Thus, the appearance of the four bands at 138, 255, 307 and 617cm−1 is indicative of the existence of tetragonal CZ phase, suggesting the phase separation of CZ for Pd/CZAB0a and Pd/CZAB4a upon thermal aging treatment. However, for Pd/CZAB6a and Pd/CZAB8a, no phase separation is observed, besides the main peak characteristic of CeO2, only two weak peaks at 307 and 617cm−1 are detected, which should be attributed to the presence of defective structure in these two samples [38]. Therefore, it can be deduced that introduction of appropriate amount of Ba can effectively enhance the structural stability of the CZA system, which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. When excessive amount of Ba is introduced, self-aggregation of BaO is certified by the strong band at 989cm−1, and in the mean time, deteriorated structure is obtained, as confirmed by the coexistence of cubic and tetragonal features in the Raman spectrum of Pd/CZAB10a. In addition, it is seen that the Raman intensities of the main cubic phase follow a sequence of Pd/CZA0a>Pd/CZAB4a>Pd/CZAB6a>Pd/CZAB8a<Pd/CZAB10a, which is in good consistency with the variation tendency of the crystallite sizes detected by XRD technique, and further sustains the positive inhibition effect of grain growth by introduction of appropriate amount of Ba. 3.4 TEM observation and EDX analysis results The TEM images of the fresh samples are presented in Fig. 4 . It is found therein that the morphologies of Pd/CZAB0-Pd/CZAB6 are similar with each other, while Pd/CZAB8 possesses relatively smaller particle size, and the primary particles of this sample are in looser contact, which may be beneficial to the suppression of grain growth upon aging treatment. In addition, it is worthwhile to point out that the morphology of Pd/CZAB10 is fundamentally different from those of Pd/CZAB0-Pd/CZAB8, as shown in Fig. 4e, some rodlike particles appear and coexist with the spherical particles. To better understand the micro-scale particle composition, EDX analysis of Pd/CZAB6-Pd/CZAB10 was performed and the results are compiled in Table 3 . According to previous studies [16,20,39], the analysis points can be identified as CZ (marked in blue) or Al2O3 (marked in red). It can be found that for Pd/CZAB6, the Ce/Zr ratios of all analysis spots are close to the theoretical value 1, meanwhile, the Ba/Al ratios also approach to the theoretical value. This observation is consistent with the XRD result that for this sample, Ba selectively combines with Al2O3, and homogeneous CZ solid solution is formed which is insusceptible to Al2O3. In the case of Pd/CZAB8, it is seen from Table 3 that the Ce/Zr ratios are also close to 1, considering the increased lattice parameter detected by XRD, it can be deduced that some Ba with larger ionic radius has entered into the framework of CZ. For Pd/CZAB10, it is found that analysis spots 1 and 4 with rodlike feature can be identified as Al2O3 particles, this agrees well with the detection of γ-Al2O3 phase by XRD. In addition, the Ba content of spot 2 (marked in white in Fig. 4e) is obviously higher than the theoretical value, which confirms the self-aggregation of BaO. 3.5 SEM observations The morphological features of the fresh and aged catalysts are characterized by SEM and the obtained images are displayed in Fig. 5 . It can be seen therein that the particles of Pd/CZAB0 are comparatively larger, and the introduction of Ba is beneficial to the formation of smaller particles, which can also inhibit the particle growth upon aging treatment. From Fig. 5(a2–e2), larger aggregates can be observed for the aged samples, which is due to the sintering process occurred during high temperature treatment. It is noticed that the particles of Pd/CZAB0a are largest, suggesting that it may undergo aggregation to the largest extent. And when Ba is introduced into the CZA system, the particle growth can be obviously suppressed, especially for Pd/CZAB8a, as shown in Fig. 5d2, Pd/CZAB8a possesses the smallest particle size, thus highest thermal stability is obtained. 3.6 XPS analysis XPS analysis was performed to study the surface elemental compositions of the fresh and aged catalysts, and the results are summarized in Table 4 . As we all know, the dispersion of noble metal species is closely related to the catalytic performance of the catalysts. From Table 4, it can be seen that the surface concentration of Pd shows an increasing tendency from Pd/CZAB0 to Pd/CZAB8. According to the literature [8], CeO2-containing components could promote the noble metal dispersion, considering the similar surface areas of these four samples, the increased surface concentration of Pd may be attributed to the increasing surface content of Ce. For Pd/CZAB10, the relatively lower surface area and declined surface Ce concentration are detrimental to the dispersion of Pd species. After aging treatment, conspicuous diminution of surface Pd concentration is observed for all samples, which can be ascribed to the severe sintering of PdOx species or the encapsulation of PdOx owing to the aggregation of the supports. And the surface concentration of Pd follows a same sequence with the specific surface area values and the surface Ce concentration, that is, Pd/CZAB10a<Pd/CZAB0a<Pd/CZAB4a<Pd/CZAB6a<Pd/CZAB8a. Particular attention should be paid to the surface Ce/Zr ratio in respect that it is closely related to the structural variation. As shown in Table 4, the Ce/Zr ratio of Pd/CZAB0 is much smaller than the theoretical value 1, which tells us that owing to the considerably high surface concentration of Al2O3, more Zr-rich species that closely contact with Al2O3 are present on the surface [20]. As proposed in the XRD and Raman sections, the introduction of Ba could facilitate the formation of more homogeneous CZ solid solutions, thus, Pd/CZAB4 and Pd/CZAB6 show increased Ce/Zr ratios. When the Ba content further increases to 8wt%, it is found that the surface concentration of Ba is close to that for Pd/CZAB6, implying that the remnant Ba may have entered into the bulk of CZ, which coincides with the XRD and Raman observations. In the case of Pd/CZAB10, self-aggregation of BaO is confirmed by the higher surface Ba concentration than the theoretical value, and deteriorated structure of CZ is verified by the Ce/Zr ratio of 1.10. After aging treatment, the surface Ce/Zr ratios of Pd/CZAB0a and Pd/CZAB4a increase, which is in line with the higher concentration of Zr in the lattice of CeO2. The surface elemental compositions of Pd/CZAB6a and Pd/CZAB8a appear only slightly different from those of the corresponding fresh catalysts, indicating the high structural stability of these two samples. With regard to Pd/CZAB10a, the surface concentration of Ba obviously increases, which agrees with the more severe self-aggregation of BaO. As reported in the literatures [40,41], for CeO2-based systems, the presence of Ce3+ can strongly affect the formation of oxygen vacancies. Fig. 6 illustrates the Ce 3d XPS spectra of the fresh and aged samples. As can be seen therein, the curves can be deconvoluted into eight peaks associated with four different spin-orbit doublets. The peaks labeled as u and v are attributed to Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, respectively. The doublet (u′, v′) is characteristic of Ce3+, while the others are all assigned to Ce4+ [42,43]. Accordingly the proportion of Ce3+ in total Ce species is calculated and the results are also listed in Table 4. It is found that the Ce3+ fraction increases from Pd/CZAB0 to Pd/CZAB8 and then decreases for Pd/CZAB10. Thus, it seems that the enhanced homogeneity of CZ solid solution could facilitate the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and consequently promote the formation of more oxygen vacancies. During the aging process, an obvious decrease of the Ce3+ proportion is observed for all samples, which is induced by sintering of the particles and oxidation of Ce3+ to Ce4+ by noble metal species [44]. In addition, the Ce3+ fraction of the aged samples shows a same sequence with that of the fresh catalysts, that is, the formation of ternary CZBa solid solution is beneficial to preserve the defective structure of Pd/CZAB8a, leading to its highest thermal stability. 3.7 TPR studies The reduction features of the CZABx compounds and the corresponding Pd/CZABx catalysts are illustrated in Figs. 7 and 8 , respectively. From Fig. 7a, it is seen that the fresh CZABx samples show quite different reduction features. As proposed in previous researches [45,46], the reduction capability of CZ-based system mainly relies on the surface area and the homogeneity of Zr distribution in the framework of CeO2. In this work, the surface areas of the fresh samples are close to each other, thus, the distinction among the reducibility is mainly associated with the homogeneity of the CZ solid solution. For CZAB0 and CZAB4, reduction peaks can be observed at both low-temperature (below 700°C) and high-temperature (above 800°C) regions, among which the low-temperature reduction feature with asymmetric shape can be ascribed to the reduction of surface and subsurface Ce4+ species, while the peak at above 800°C is usually attributed to the reduction of bulk Ce4+ species and is intrinsic to CeO2 [45,47]. As declared in the literature [46], the incorporation of ZrO2 into the lattice of CeO2 could enlarge the lattice space and consequently facilitate the migration of oxygen atoms. Thus, it is understandable that owing to the comparatively low content of Zr in the lattice of CeO2 for CZAB0 and CZAB4, undesirable bulk oxygen mobility is obtained, resulting in the appearance of the high-temperature reduction peak. As revealed in the XRD and Raman sections, for CZAB6, homogeneous CZ solid solution is formed, and consequently enhanced bulk oxygen mobility is obtained, therefore, CZAB6 features only one reduction peak, which is similar with the reduction characteristic of single Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 compound [35,48,49]. When the content of Ba reaches 8wt%, the remnant Ba enters into the lattice of CZ to form ternary CZBa solid solution, which further facilitates the formation of more oxygen vacancies and thus enhanced reduction ability is obtained. However, introduction of excessive amount of Ba seriously destroys the structure of CZAB10 by self-aggregation of BaO, and consequently declined reducibility is obtained. Thermal aging treatment brings about significant changes of the reduction behaviors. Owing to the sintering process, decreased reduction ability is obtained for the aged samples, and thus lower intensities of the reduction peaks are observed. As shown in Fig. 7b, the high-temperature reduction peaks of CZAB0 and CZAB4 disappear after aging, which is attributed to the improved bulk oxygen mobility caused by the migration of more Zr4+ species into the lattice of CeO2. Fortunately, CZAB6a and CZAB8a still maintain better reduction ability. For CZAB10a, the self-aggregation of BaO is more obvious, which leads to seriously deteriorated structure of CZ, and the multi-modal feature of the reduction peaks is closely related to its inhomogeneous structure. When Pd is loaded onto the CZABx supports, as seen in Fig. 8a, the reduction of the catalysts takes place at relatively low temperatures, that is, below 200°C, which can be ascribed to the reduction of PdO species according to the literatures [50,51]. However, what should be noticed is that the loading amount of Pd is extremely low (0.5wt%), thus attribution of the whole reduction below 200°C to PdO species only seems inaccurate. As described in the literature [52], for CZ-supported Pd catalysts, the reduction of CeO2 can be remarkably promoted by the noble metal species. Therefore, the reduction features in Fig. 8a are ascribed to the reduction of PdO species accompanied by some Pd-promoted reduction of the supports. As claimed in the literature [53], the low-temperature reducibility of the catalysts is of pivotal importance in respect that the associated oxygen is most available during practical catalytic operation. And it is seen that the reducibility of the fresh catalysts follows a sequence of Pd/CZAB0<Pd/CZAB4<Pd/CZAB6<Pd/CZAB8>Pd/CZAB10. Thus, the highest surface Pd concentration and the most defective structure of Pd/CZAB8 are highly responsible for its best reducibility. After aging treatment, noticeable changes take place for all catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 8b, declined reducibility compared with that of the fresh samples is observed, which is mainly caused by sintering of both the noble metal species and the supports. A negative peak at about 60°C is seen for all samples, which is originated from the decomposition of PdHx. In general, metallic Pd would adsorb hydrogen to form PdHx even at room temperature and quite low hydrogen pressure [52,54]. During the temperature-programmed reduction process, PdHx could easily be decomposed and the generated hydrogen species consequently gives rise to the appearance of the negative peak in the TPR profile. In addition, the reducibility of the aged catalysts shows the same sequence with that of the fresh samples, that is, Pd/CZAB8a owns the highest thermal stability and the reducibility can be preserved to the largest extent during thermal aging process, which is beneficial to suppress the deactivation of the catalytic performance. 3.8 Three-way catalytic performance The three-way catalytic performance was evaluated, and the results, including the conversions of HC, CO, NO and the N2 selectivity, are reported in Figs. 9 and 10 , respectively. For the fresh catalysts, the conversion efficiency and the N2 selectivity show a same sequence of Pd/CZAB0<Pd/CZAB4<Pd/CZAB6<Pd/CZAB8>Pd/CZAB10. That is, when Ba is introduced into the CZA system, the corresponding catalysts exhibit increasing catalytic activities with the content of Ba increasing to 8wt%, while excessive amount of Ba is detrimental to the catalytic performance. Considering the similar textural properties of these samples, the differences in the catalytic performance is mainly dependent on the structural and reduction properties. As discussed above, the homogeneity of CZ solid solution is enhanced by the introduction of Ba (≤6wt%), and ternary CZBa solid solution is formed for Pd/CZAB8, which further facilitates the generation of more oxygen vacancies. However, the deteriorated structure of Pd/CZAB10 leads to undesirable oxygen mobility. The XPS results tell us that the surface concentration of Pd increases from Pd/CZAB0 to Pd/CZAB8, and the Ce3+ fraction associated with the formation of oxygen vacancies shows the same tendency, which contribute well to the increasing catalytic performance. For Pd/CZAB10, the lower surface concentration of Pd and the declined Ce3+ fraction are responsible for the declined catalytic activity. In addition, improved reducibility is obtained with the doping amount of Ba increasing from 0 to 8wt%, and Pd/CZAB10 owns declined reducibility, which well matches with the three-way catalytic performance. From Fig. 10, degraded catalytic performance of the aged catalysts is observed, which is mainly attributed to the sintering of supports and noble metal particles, as well as the reduction of PdO to Pd at high temperature [55]. Similar with the fresh samples, the aged catalysts also show increasing catalytic performance from Pd/CZAB0a to Pd/CZAB8a, and declined catalytic activity is obtained for Pd/CZAB10a. Thus it is clear that the introduction of appropriate amount of Ba into the CZA system is beneficial to enhance the thermal stability of the catalysts. Owing to the relatively high specific surface area and large pore volume of Pd/CZAB8a, the catalytic reaction can more easily happen. And the high structural stability helps maintain large amount of oxygen vacancies, which facilitates the improvement of oxygen mobility. Furthermore, the highest surface concentration of Pd and superior reducibility of Pd/CZAB8a are of pivotal importance to its excellent catalytic performance. In addition, aging experiments were performed under hydrothermal conditions (1000°C/5h in the presence of 10vol% H2O) which reflect more closely those of the real TWC applications, and the results are depicted in Fig. S1. Compared with the results in Fig. 10, the reactions take place at relatively higher temperatures for the hydrothermally aged catalysts, which is due to the more severe sintering. And the catalytic performance of the five catalysts follow the same tendency with that of the thermally aged samples, which again confirms that introduction of appropriate amount of Ba (8wt%) into the CZA system can obtain a composite more suitable to use as support in three-way catalyst. 4 Conclusions The introduction of Ba into the CZA system is found to be highly effective in modifying the textural, structural and reduction properties, as well as enhancing the catalytic performance of the supported Pd-only three-way catalyst. With low doping amount (≤6wt%), Ba can preferentially combine with Al2O3 and acts as a stabilizer, and in the meantime, enhanced homogeneity of CZ solid solution is obtained. When the content of BaO increases to 8wt%, besides the portion combined with Al2O3, the remnant Ba would enter into the lattice of CeO2–ZrO2 to form a ternary CeO2–ZrO2–BaO solid solution, thus further increased oxygen mobility is obtained, resulting in excellent reducibility and catalytic performance of Pd/CZAB8. However, excessive amount of Ba (10wt%) may bring about self-aggregation of BaO, which deteriorates the structure, and consequently leads to declined reducibility and catalytic performance of Pd/CZAB10. In addition, the synergistic effect between CZ/CZBa and BaO–Al2O3 helps improve the thermal stability of the composite system. With the optimal doping amount of Ba, Pd/CZAB8 displays highest thermal stability, that is, it maintains best textural and structural properties among all the aged samples. Meanwhile, the surface concentration of Pd and oxygen vacancies are preserved to the largest extent, which consequently gives rise to best reducibility and superior catalytic performance of Pd/CZAB8a. coredata.dc:description: In this work, CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3 (CZA) composites promoted by selective doping with Ba were prepared by simple coprecipitation method. The structural characterization results reveal that with small doping amount (≤6wt%), Ba can preferentially combine with Al2O3 and acts as a stabilizer, which could facilitate the formation of more homogeneous CZ solid solutions. When the content of BaO increases to 8wt%, besides the portion combined with Al2O3, the remnant Ba would enter into the lattice of CeO2–ZrO2 to form a ternary CeO2–ZrO2–BaO solid solution, thus further improved oxygen mobility is obtained. However, excessive doping amount (10wt%) brings about self-aggregation of BaO, which seriously deteriorates the structure of the CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3-BaO composite. The XPS results demonstrate that with optimal doping content of BaO (8wt%), the supported catalyst Pd/CZAB8 possesses highest surface Pd and Ce3+ concentrations, which consequently leads to improved reducibility and catalytic performance. Furthermore, the synergistic effect between CeO2–ZrO2–BaO and BaO–Al2O3 helps improve the thermal stability of Pd/CZAB8. Thus, superior textural, structural, morphological and reduction properties along with enhanced three-way catalytic performance are obtained for aged Pd/CZAB8a.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion of CeO2–ZrO2–Al2O3 composite by selective doping with barium and its supported Pd-only three-way catalyst
